cards.label: Pain Severity
cards.value: Planning is overwhelming and disruptions are stressful.

detail.title: How Painful Is This for Gen Z?
detail.summary: Gen Z feels overloaded when planning trips and especially anxious when things go wrong mid-travel.
points: People jump between TikTok, Google, and booking sites trying to piece together a good trip.
When flights are canceled or plans fall apart, users feel stuck and don’t know what to do.
These stressful moments are when people most want real help, not just another app.

cards.label: Problem Frequency
cards.value: Happens a few times every year.

detail.title: How Often Does This Happen?
detail.summary: Trip planning isn’t constant, but it happens often enough to form habits.
points: Most Gen Z travelers take around 3–5 trips a year.
Each trip triggers hours or days of research across different platforms.
Travel problems tend to repeat, so people remember who helped them last time.

detail.title: People Already Spend a Lot on This
detail.summary: This isn’t a new behavior — people already pay for help with travel.
points: U.S. travel agencies are expected to make about $46.9B in revenue in 2025.
Gen Z group trips often cost $2,000–$3,000 per person.
The challenge isn’t getting people to care about travel — it’s getting them to switch tools.

cards.label: Competitive Landscape
cards.value: Lots of options, mostly feel the same.

detail.title: What People Use Today
detail.summary: Most people book through big online platforms that focus on price and speed.
points: Major players include Expedia, Booking.com, Airbnb, and Google Travel.
These tools are good for finding deals but not for guidance or reassurance.
Users often feel like they’re on their own when things go wrong.

cards.label: Competitive Gaps
cards.value: No trusted guide from discovery to booking.

detail.title: What’s Missing Today
detail.summary: Current tools help people book, but not feel confident.
points: People discover trips on social media but can’t easily turn that into real plans.
There’s little real human support when plans fall apart.
Pricing often feels confusing and unpredictable.

cards.label: Market Dynamics
cards.value: Travel ideas come from social, not search.

detail.title: How People Find Trips Now
detail.summary: Gen Z gets inspired by creators, not travel ads.
points: TikTok and Instagram are major sources of travel inspiration.
People trust recommendations from creators more than brands.
Booking still happens on old-school platforms that feel disconnected.

detail.title: What Could Slow This Down
detail.summary: Running a travel agency has rules, but nothing unusual.
points: Some states require travel sellers to register.
There are rules around refunds and disclosures.
Mistakes in bookings can create liability.

detail.title: The Hard Part of Building This
detail.summary: People want human help, but humans are expensive.
points: High-quality service usually means more staff.
Margins in travel are thin.
Technology has to reduce workload without losing trust.

detail.title: Where to Start
detail.summary: Start with the most painful moments.
points: Flight cancellations and missed connections.
Chat-based help instead of long call centers.
Focus on short, common trips first.

detail.title: Why This Could Work
detail.summary: This product lives where Gen Z already is.
points: Trips start from social posts.
Creators bring trust and attention.
AI helps scale human-style support.

detail.title: Are People Ready for This?
detail.summary: The idea makes sense, but behavior still needs to be tested.
points: People like the idea of guidance.
They still default to booking sites.
The key question is whether they’ll actually switch.

detail.title: How Big Could This Be?
detail.summary: The market is large, but hard to win.
points: Millions of Gen Z travelers book trips every year.
Most money already flows through big platforms.
Winning even a small share could be meaningful.

detail.title: Reality Check
detail.summary: This is more about trust and habits than technology.
points: Strength: people feel lost planning trips.
Weakness: switching tools is hard.
Opportunity: become the trusted travel helper.
Threat: big platforms can copy features.
